repnme.cdata!: Maldives - Third Education and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Education and
            Training Project of Maldives were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: 1) In small countries, projects often involve
            multiple ministries and limited personnel to carry out key
            tasks. Projects can still be successfully implemented when
            there is a strong stakeholder commitment to reform and when
            these is the political and administrative commitment to set
            high-quality standards, to monitor progress, and to make
            flexible changes as necessary; 2) It is important to locate
            the unit that coordinates implementation under the major
            implementing Ministry, so that the senior official/s with
            that Ministry are able to provide the necessary authority
            for the project to progress and to avoid implementation
            delays; 3) Quality reforms and those involving institutional
            capacity building tend to need extended periods of time to
            firmly take root in changed thinking and practice, and
            therefore to have an attributable effect on staff and
            student learning; 4) Regular and functional school-level
            supervision, along with parental/community involvement to
            provide feedback on aspects of the learning environment
            (e.g. textbooks), are important to make needed changes to
            improve student learning; and 5) Recruitment from the outset
            of qualified staff is essential for ensuring strong and
            consistent project implementation progress.

repnme.cdata!: Maldives - Third Education and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education and Training Project
            will improve quality of education in Maldives, increase
            equitable access, and strengthen institutional capacity. The
            components are: 1) Education quality improvement, to raise
            learning achievements at the primary, lower and upper
            secondary levels. Teacher training will be provided through
            atoll-based in-service learning to upgrade teachers'
            skills, and improve staff development for school
            supervisors. The primary school curriculum will be improved,
            and a publishing capacity developed for textbooks upgrading.
            In addition, a system of national assessment will be
            developed, for improved student assessment practices and
            achievements, with a focus on reforming the public
            examination system. 2) Equitable access, to be increased
            through the expansion of secondary schools. The component
            includes construction, and upgrading of facilities at the
            Atoll Education Centers, providing library services, science
            equipment and laboratories, in addition to teacher training
            at the atoll schools. 3) Institutional strengthening, to
            improve planning and implementation of educational programs.
            Capacity building will be achieved through the provision of
            technical assistance for the development of an Education
            Management Information System, expanding as well the
            information links to the atolls. 4) Training for selected
            professionals, provided through external fellowships.
